div1.head: Military Orders for James Pilcher and Guy Charles Moore Godfrey, October 16, 1900 [selected pages]
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec Orders Vol 2
1900

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, October 16, 1900.

1. By direction of the Secretary of War, Acting Hospital
Steward Earl H. Eddy and six privates, Hospital Corps, Army
General Hospital, Washington Barracks, District of Columbia,
will be sent to Fort Columbus, New York, and will report upon
arrival to the commanding officer of that post pending assign-
ment to duty on transport service. The commanding general,
Department of the East. Governors Island, New York, will
assign Steward Eddy and three of these privates to duty on
the transport “Buford;” the other three and Acting Hospital
Steward Otto F. Frese, Hospital Corps, will be assigned by
him to duty aboard the transport “Kilpatrick.” They will be
sent aboard the vessels designated when their services are in
the opinion of the medical superintendent, Army transport serv-
ice, New York City, required thereon.

2. By direction of the Secretary of War, Corporal Conrad
Kuhleman, Battery L, 1st Artillery, Fort Barrancas, Florida,
will be discharged from the Army, by way of favor, by the
commanding officer of his station. This soldier is not entitled
to travel-pay.

3. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private William
Hayes, Company E, 7th Infantry, now at the Army and Navy
General Hospital, Hot Springs, Arkansas, will be discharged
without honor from the Army by the commanding officer of
that hospital, by reason of having become disqualified for
service through his own fault. This soldier is not entitled to
travel-pay.

4. By direction of the Secretary of War, Drum Major
George D. Kees, band, 1st Infantry, now at Fort Leavenworth,
Kansas, is transferred as a private to the U. S. Military Acad-
emy band, West Point, New York. He will be sent to that
post and will report upon arrival to the commanding officer
for duty. The expenses of the transfer will be borne by the
soldier and transportation will not be furnished by the Quar-
termaster's Department.

5. By direction of the Secretary of War, the retirement
2
from active service by the President, to take effect November
1, 1900, of Colonel James W. Scully, assistant quartermaster
general, U. S. Army, upon his own application, under the pro-
visions of section 1244, Revised Statutes, he having attained
the age of sixty-two years, is announced. Colonel Scully will
proceed to his home on or after the date specified. The travel
enjoined is necessary for the public service.

6. By direction of the Secretary of War, Captain Samuel
A. Smoke, 5th U. S. Infantry, will report in person to the com-
manding officer, Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, for examination
by a medical officer at that post as to his present physical con-
dition, and upon the completion of the examination will
return to the place of receipt by him of this order. The travel
enjoined is necessary for the public service.

7. By direction of the Secretary of War, Captain James E.
Pilcher, assistant surgeon, U. S. Army, will report in person
to the commanding officer, Fort McHenry, Maryland, for ex-
amination by a medical officer at that post as to his physical
condition, and upon the completion of the examination will
return to the place of receipt by him of this order. The travel
enjoined is necessary for the public service.

8. By direction of the Secretary of War, Captain Guy C. M.
Godfrey, assistant surgeon, U. S. Army, now in Brooklyn,
New York, en route to San Francisco, California, under para-
graph 25, Special Orders, No. 185, August 8, 1900, is relieved
from the further operation of the order specified and will
report in person on or about November 7, 1900, to the com-
manding general, Department of the East, for assignment to
duty with recruits en route to the Philippine Islands on the
transport “Kilpatrick.” Upon his arrival at Manila and the
completion of his duty with the recruits he will report in per-
son to the commanding general, Division of the Philippines, for
further orders.

9. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major John M.
Carson, jr., quartermaster, U. S. Volunteers, will proceed from
this city to Fort Morgan and Fort Gaines, Alabama; Fort
Barrancas, Fort Pickens, Fort Dade, and Fort DeSoto, Florida;
Fort Screven, Georgia; Fort Moultrie and Fort Fremont,
South Carolina; Fort Caswell, North Carolina, and Fort Mon-
